Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Researching Muslim America and Muslim Americans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing size and political relevancy of the Muslim population in the U.S. stands in stark contrast to the trivial amount of quality data describing their political attitudes and behavior. As a first step in planning and conducting a large-N, in-depth, multilingual survey of this understudied community, a full day workshop will bring together a diverse set of participants including faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates. Workshop participants will summarize and discuss the current state of knowledge about Muslims Americans and coordinate next steps. Participants will include faculty and graduate students who currently study Muslim Americans or who are interested in doing so. Gathering researchers together to promote collaboration and discuss recent research will 1) encourage scholars to work in this area, 2) ensure that future efforts to better understand Muslim Americans are inclusive of a broad range of research questions and hypotheses, and 3) facilitate cooperation and coordination among scholars (including graduate students). The networking of scholars, including the mentoring of junior scholars and students by senior faculty, will strengthen the diversity and quality of future scholarship and the profession.

The Workshop will address several important topics in the studying of members of ethnic and/or religious groups. These include issues of identity, effects of discrimination and media coverage, political behavior, and political attitude. In addition, it will help to develop a research agenda for scholars studying these groups include a national survey. Finally, the workshop will increase synergies between faculty and graduate students of diverse backgrounds, which will in turn develop networks and collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Muslim American Politics Workshop

Muslims represent just 1% of the total population of the U.S., but are a persistent and increasingly important subject of national political conversations. The increasing size and political relevancy of the Muslim population in the U.S. stands in stark contrast to the amount of existing political science scholarship on their political attitudes and behavior. As a first step in planning and conducting additional research focused on this understudied community, NSF funding was used to bring together faculty and graduate students for two full-day workshops. The first was held at Menlo College in Atherton, California, on December 16, 2017. A year later, a follow-up meeting was held at UCLA, on December 15, 2018.

The workshops aimed to summarize existing knowledge and spark new research projects, while also facilitating networking and mentoring among the small number of scholars in the U.S. who are interested in Muslim American politics. Prior to the 2017 workshop, no conference or workshop had brought together race and ethnic politics scholars who focus on Muslim Americans. 

Workshop organizers included Nazita Lajevardi, now Assistant Professor of Political Science at Michigan State University, Melissa R. Michelson, professor of political science at Menlo College, and Brian Calfano, a professor in journalism and political science at the University of Cincinnati. Panels at the workshops included: a) the formation and reinforcement of Muslim American group identity in the post 9/11 period, b) the effects on Muslim Americans in the post-9/11 period of perceived racism and discrimination by the general public (including thought leaders such as Trump) and c) the media, d) Muslim American political behavior over time (including the 2016 electoral cycle), and e) measurement of Muslim American policy preferences and political attitudes, including feelings of belonging/exclusion. A reading list in the form of an annotated bibliography was distributed to workshop participants prior to their arrival at the 2016 meeting. More about the 2016 meeting can be found at https://www.menlo.edu/events/muslim-americans-workshop/.  New work published in the intervening year was highlighted at the 2017 meeting.

To date, the workshop has generated several publications, including a review essay about the 2016 workshop authored by the PIs (“Trumped Up Challenges: Limitations, Opportunities, and the Future of Political Research on Muslim Americans,” Politics, Groups, and Identities, DOI: 10.1080/21565503.2017.1386573).

In addition, participants have worked to organized panels at the 2017 and 2018 annual meetings of the American Political Science Association, and have contributed to a forthcoming book from Temple University Press, edited by Drs. Lajevardi and Calfano, as well as to a special issue of the journal Religion & Politics. The PIs and participants continue to research the subject and build on the networks and ideas generated by the NSF workshops, contributing to our knowledge about how Muslim Americans think and behave in the U.S. political arena.
